bibl.note: This is a letter from G. W. Martin to Andrew J. Donelson, dated June 31, 1834. Martin has been traveling around the south gaging people's opinions about the government. He writes that they are being misused by their politicians. Martin has many derogatory things to say about the prominent Mississippian politician George Poindexter. He also writes that the people are against the Bank of the U. S.

div1.p: I am just returned from a journey of some four to six hundred miles, passing through many of the most interesting country in the state and have had every facility of discovering the un biased if a liberal opinion of the people generally, and I am constrained here to aver there never has been a people more abused, more misrepresented both by their polititians particularly at Washington City, as well by a hot headed set of self important would be great men whose views are supported by some half a dozen people menings millers Bankers if of swelled head

But sir let me once and for all tell you these Mississippians with the above exceptions are brave to the chosen they are opposed to Bank U. S. they are dis
gusted with allarmests whom they set down clay calhoun the leading maj ? they hesitate not in saying Jno. Black` has forfeted his most solemn pledge, and as for Cage pose dever they almost would seem to pity him they say he has been over reached by the master spirits and seem to be desposed to let pleasure carry or skorge him with mipos for the present, Knowing on what hobby he rode to Congress they have a rod in ? should he ever presume to so want himself again for their sufrage ; and last but not least that Fungus car bunkle Hungry ever and Incubus George Poindexter of surstun nerur memory (on the 8th Jany 1815) whose bowels yearned hediously at the diabolical smell of sulfurous gunpowder, whos eyes blinked at the rockets glowe , while his Kines smote other on hearing the mighty cannon roar
and with the exeplory above made the Mississippians one and all say away with this vile slanderer of both men and priciple , tar & feather is spanker of as suitable appeal&c

Again these people are true to justise & principle tho they are much abused not only on the mortification to have ther state misrepresented & shown to the D C Bank they are also nselhel on their private feeling the best administration men in the state nearly recur a preble dream or speak in its support, while every Farm town & vilage teaming with speaches on speaches & pamphlet on pamphlet talking of revolution, war pestilen & pain , Bank Eulayes Jackson Tyrany &c &c
